hints_html: The question is looking for the derivative of \(f(x)\). Since this function is definted as a composition of functions, we need to use the chain rule.
hints_latex:
The question is looking for the derivative of $f(x)$. Since this
function is definted as a composition of functions, we need to use the
chain rule.
hints_raw: The question is looking for the derivative of <math>f(x)</math>. Since this function is definted as a composition of functions, we need to use the chain rule.
question: 2 (d)
sols_html:
Taking the derivative gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = g'(2\sin(x))(2\cos(x))\end{aligned}\]

Plugging in \(x = \pi/4\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} f'(\pi/4) &= g'(2\sin(\pi/4))(2\cos(\pi/4)) \\ &= g'(2\cdot\tfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}})\cdot 2\cdot \tfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ &= g'(\sqrt{2})\cdot \sqrt{2} \\ &= \sqrt{2}\cdot \sqrt{2} \\ &= 2\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Taking the derivative gives

:<math> \displaystyle
f'(x) = g'(2\sin(x))(2\cos(x))
</math>

Plugging in <math> x = \pi/4 </math> gives

:<math>
\begin{align}
f'(\pi/4) &= g'(2\sin(\pi/4))(2\cos(\pi/4)) \\
&= g'(2\cdot\tfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}})\cdot 2\cdot \tfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
&= g'(\sqrt{2})\cdot \sqrt{2} \\
&= \sqrt{2}\cdot \sqrt{2} \\
&= 2
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Questions 1-4 are short-answer questions. Put your answers in the boxes provided. Simplify your answers as much as possible, and show your work. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Let \(\displaystyle f(x) = g(2\sin x)\), where \(g'(\sqrt{2}) = \sqrt{2}\). Find \(\displaystyle f'(\pi/4)\)
